recommendations: Perform CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE) to rule out pulmonary embolism.
Obtain recent eGFR before administering contrast for CT Pulmonary Angiography.
If eGFR is < 30 mL/min/1.73m², consider non-contrast CT of the chest for alternative imaging if clinically appropriate, or proceed with caution and hydration as per ACR guidelines.
Consider a low-dose non-contrast CT chest if the primary concern shifts to lung cancer screening and renal function is a significant contraindication to contrast.
rationale: Patient presents with shortness of breath and chest pain, which are primary indications for CT Pulmonary Angiography.
Absence of eGFR necessitates verification to assess contrast safety, aligning with KDIGO and ACR guidelines.
Patient's history of diabetes and hypertension are risk factors for renal impairment, increasing the importance of eGFR assessment before contrast.
Non-emergency admission allows for standard protocol preparation and risk assessment.
Low-dose non-contrast CT chest is a viable alternative if contrast administration is contraindicated due to renal insufficiency and the clinical question can be addressed.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.

protocol_selection.name: Low-Dose CT Chest – Lung Cancer Screening
protocol_selection.description: Low-dose CT of lungs targeting <3 mGy radiation dose while maintaining image quality.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ideal in patients with renal dysfunction due to non-use of contrast.
